tips.title: Seek Dark Skies
tips.description: Find a location away from city lights. The darker the sky, the more you will see. Use a light pollution map to find the best spots near you.

tips.title: Check the Weather
tips.description: A clear, cloudless night is essential for good viewing. Check the forecast for cloud cover, humidity, and atmospheric seeing conditions.

tips.title: Let Your Eyes Adapt
tips.description: It takes about 20-30 minutes for your eyes to fully adapt to the dark. Avoid looking at bright screens. Use a red flashlight to preserve your night vision.

tips.title: Use the Right Gear
tips.description: Binoculars are a great starting point for exploring the Moon and star clusters. A telescope will reveal more distant galaxies and nebulae.

interactiveTelescope.title: Know Your Gear: Telescope Anatomy
interactiveTelescope.prompt: Hover over a part of the telescope to learn about it.

objective.name: Objective Lens / Mirror
objective.description: The primary optical element. It gathers the faint light from distant objects and focuses it. The larger the diameter (aperture), the brighter and more detailed the image will be.

tube.name: Optical Tube
tube.description: The main body of the telescope. It holds the optics in alignment and blocks out stray light to ensure a high-contrast image.

eyepiece.name: Eyepiece & Focuser
eyepiece.description: The eyepiece magnifies the focused image from the objective lens. The focuser moves it to achieve a sharp view. You can change eyepieces for different magnifications.

mount.name: Equatorial Mount & Tripod
mount.description: The foundation of the telescope. It provides stability and allows aiming. This equatorial mount is designed to follow the rotation of the sky with a single motion.

finderscope.name: Finderscope
finderscope.description: A small, secondary telescope mounted on the main scope. It has a wider field of view, making it easier to locate objects before viewing them through the main eyepiece.

tips.title: Use a Sturdy Mount
tips.description: A stable base is non-negotiable. For long exposures, a star tracker or equatorial mount is essential to prevent star trails and capture sharp details.

tips.title: Master Manual Focus
tips.description: Use your camera's live view, zoom in on a bright star, and adjust the focus ring until the star is a tiny, sharp point of light. A Bahtinov mask can help achieve perfection.

tips.title: Shoot in RAW
tips.description: RAW files capture all the sensor data, giving you maximum flexibility in post-processing to bring out faint details and correct colors.

tips.title: The Exposure Triangle
tips.description: Use a wide aperture (e.g., f/2.8), a moderate ISO (800-1600), and the longest shutter speed your mount allows without trails.

tips.title: Polar Align Carefully
tips.description: If using a tracker, take your time with polar alignment. This is the most important step for getting sharp, round stars in long exposures.

tips.title: Plan Your Shoot
tips.description: Know what you want to capture before you go out. Use apps like Stellarium or SkySafari to see what objects are visible and plan your composition.

tips.title: Use an Intervalometer
tips.description: A remote shutter or intervalometer lets you take photos without touching the camera, preventing vibrations that can blur your images.

tips.title: Stack Your Images
tips.description: Take many identical exposures ('lights') and stack them later in software like DeepSkyStacker to reduce noise and reveal faint details.
